Woman on the Edge of Time follows the lives of three women, all of whom are connected by their strong ties to the past, and their even stronger desires to shape the future. These women feel a political and personal urgency about leaving their mark on history, and this feeling ultimately becomes a catalyst for the novel's plot.

The first woman, Molly, lives in the 1970s and works in a prison for delinquent girls. She becomes involved in a political organization called Unit 25, and is portrayed as a woman whose ideals are more theoretical than real. She is kind-hearted, but unable to make a real difference in the girls' lives due to the systemic nature of the prison.

The second woman, Alia, lives in 2000, in a post-apocalyptic world caused by a violent revolution that occurred roughly halfway through the 20th century. It is unclear whether Molly and Alia are the same character, due to the unusual nature of time in the novel; Alia believes she is a visitor from an alternate future, rather than the true future. She travels between various times and places, including the 1970s and an indigenous reservation, in her quest to obtain a powerful and dangerous new drug called Methedrine.

The third woman, Connie, lives in 2500. She is a "time warrior", working to obtain information about the past that will help her fellow time warriors determine the course of the future. Connie is also Alia's daughter, although she does not realize this until towards the end of the novel. Connie travels to the 1970s to meet Molly, with the intention of saving her – and herself – from the tragic life that Molly is destined to lead.

The novel follows the story of a strange green-skinned child who is found in a cave by a group of children. The children take the child to their village, where he is welcomed by the villagers. However, as the child grows older, it becomes more and more apparent that he is not like the other children. He is taller and stronger, and he has an uncanny ability to communicate with animals. He is also extremely sensitive to the beauty of the world around him, and he is able to see things that others cannot. 

As the child grows into adulthood, he begins to feel a strong desire to explore the world beyond the village. He sets out on a journey to discover the truth about his own identity and to find out where he comes from. Along the way, he meets a variety of characters, including a wise old man who teaches him about the ways of the world, and a beautiful woman who captures his heart.

The novel follows the green child's journey of self-discovery as he learns about the world and about himself. It is a story of adventure, love, and the search for truth.

In 1927, an illiterate French prostitute named Marie Bashkirtseff (also transcribed as Maria Bashkirtseff) commits suicide at the age of 25. Her mother, a Russian noblewoman, had forced her into prostitution to earn money after Marie's father abandoned the family for a younger woman. Marie records her life story in a journal, which is published after her death and becomes a best seller. A British actress named Iris Storm buys the film rights to the story and begins recruiting actors for a movie based on Marie's life.

In present-day Paris, Guillaume Musse is a translator and bachelor in his forties. He is estranged from his family and has a strained relationship with his lover, Claire. While attending a party with Claire, he meets an actress named Sofia and immediately becomes infatuated with her. When Sofia's boyfriend breaks up with her, Guillaume rents an apartment for her and begins supporting her financially. Gradually, Sofia becomes more and more demanding, expecting Guillaume to pay for expensive gifts and clothing. To support Sofia, Guillaume must take a job as an editor for a large luxury hotel, translating the dreams of recently deceased guests. He also has sex with wealthy older men in exchange for money.

One day, Guillaume meets Iris while walking Sofia's dog. She tells him about Marie's life and how it was immortalized in the journal. Iris also says that she went to great lengths to make the film accurate, even going so far as to recruit Sofia for the role of Marie. After learning that Sofia is having an affair with Guillaume, Iris decides that Sofia is unfit for the role of Marie and attempts to persuade Guillaume to abandon her. When Guillaume refuses, Iris reveals that she has terminal cancer and will soon die.

Guillaume's friend, Pierre, a television producer, offers him a job recording a documentary about the luxury hotel. While making the documentary, Guillaume learns that the hotel was built on the site of an old brothel where Marie once worked. He also discovers a secret room containing the discarded belongings of former guests. In particular, he is drawn to a green dress, which he gives to Sofia.

Guillaume's relationship with Sofia gradually disintegrates, and he begins seeing a woman named Elisa, who works at the hotel. Eventually, Sofia moves in with a new boyfriend, leaving Guillaume to pay for the apartment and her other expenses. He records Sofia's dreams in the journal, hoping to publish them and make money. Babywise is a book written by Gary E. Morrish and Robert Bucknam, M.D., published in 1993, summarizing the advice of Dr. Bucknam's program, whose principles derive from attachment theory and the "continuum concept" of parenting. The book outlines a program which details how parents can care for their babies such that the babies sleep through the night early on. The practice avoids "sleep training" in favor of training the parents to respond to their infant's cues.

The book suggests that parents interpret their baby's cues and, in response, put the baby to sleep in their crib at bedtime and whenever they wake up–never letting the baby cry until tired enough to fall asleep. The authors claim this will enable the baby to sleep for longer periods. The approach urges parents to "be sensitive" to their baby's cues "and avoid letting the baby get overly tired."

The book's authors say that crib sleeping is healthy and preferable for a baby's sleep, that a baby's sleep patterns are more efficiently established by being put to bed awake rather than asleep, and that a baby will sleep longer if placed in a crib when sleepy rather than completely asleep. The authors cite the importance of the parent-infant attachment relationship, and of nighttime parenting.

The book has sold over 150,000 copies. It has been criticized by some pediatricians and parenting experts as being "too rigid" and "unreasonable", and for promoting practices that may lead to infant sleep neglect and failure to respond to a baby's cries.

Truth and Bright Water is a novel written by American author Terry Tempest Williams. It follows Williams' memoir, Refuge: An Unnatural History of Family and Place, which describes her childhood in the Mormon religion in Idaho and Utah, and her grief at the death of her mother. In Truth and Bright Water, Williams intersects these themes with an account of thetangypanis.com vacation house she and her husband, the photographer Stephen Trimble, built in the Red Cliffs Desert Reserve in southern Utah. The house is located in a dried-up lake bed, and they nickname it "Desolation."

Williams became interested in the lake bed while coping with the death of her mother and her own battle with breast cancer, both of which occurred as she and Trimble were building their vacation house. In the course of researching the history of the desert region, Williams learned that the lake bed had once been a recreational site for dinosaurs, then prehistoric humans, then the Ancestral Pueblos, and later the Fremont culture. Finally, it was used for farming by the Mormon settlers before becoming a neglected, dried-up lake bed once more.

As Williams ponders these successive occupations of the land, she describes the history of the region as "a story of forgetting". She analyzes the role that her own religion, Mormonism, played in the process of desecrating the land in the name of progress. In particular, she explores the way that the Mormon conception of history as a process of destruction and renewal affects their relationship to the land. She also describes the way that the contemporary Mormon practice of storing sacred texts in vaults is analogous to the way in which the prehistoric Pueblo people buried their own sacred objects in the land.

Williams weaves these reflections on religion and history together with a narrative of her relationship with her mother and with the land itself, as well as an account of the geological and ecological history of the region. She explores the similarities between the processes of dying and being born, and describes the death of her mother as a painful but ultimately transformative experience. She also describes the process of building her house as a form of rebirth, and suggests that the house itself is a kind of baby.

As a whole, Truth and Bright Water is a complex and multifaceted work that explores themes of history, religion, ecology, and grief. It is both a personal narrative and a philosophical meditation on the relationship between individuals and the land they inhabit.

The plot summary for Der Schrecksenmeister is as follows:

In the final years of Kaiser Wilhelm II's reign, Germany is gradually losing World War I. Wallenstein is engaged in collecting taxes for the crown in the snowy mountains of Bohemia. He hates this work, as it brings him no glory, but his employer, Obersturmbannführer Kinski, is a powerful friend whom he cannot afford to offend. While away on business, Wallenstein's wife, Martha, has an affair with a major who is also a spy for the French. When Wallenstein returns, he sees a letter from the major addressed to Martha and, during an argument, he kills her. Later, when the major is arrested and tortured, he does not betray Martha but instead accuses Wallenstein of murder. At his trial, Wallenstein suddenly announces that he wishes to confess to the murder. However, when he is brought to the scene of the crime, he grabs a shovel and digs through the snow until he finds Martha's body. When he discovers that it has already been unearthed and is lying on a sheet, he suddenly stops and confesses to the murder, but his mind has gone; he can no longer remember what he really did. The judge sentences him to one day in prison, with credit for time served, and he is released immediately. Later, Wallenstein is relieved to learn that the major died under torture and that Kinski has arranged for him to be promoted to the rank of captain.

Agatha Raisin's marriage to James Lacey is crumbling. After a public argument, James moves out of their Chelsea home to live with his girlfriend, and Agatha follows suit, deciding to stay at her holiday cottage in the village of Carsely. The village is full of old friends, as well as a few enemies, but Agatha is relieved to be home.

Carsely has a spring festival approaching with a dance. All the available men are excited at the prospect, but Agatha admits to her friend Sir Charles Fraith that she no longer seems to attract men. Then the festival's fortune teller, Madame Bella, predicts that Agatha's life is about to change for the better. But when Bella is found strangled to death in a tent, Agatha realizes it is up to her to find the killer.

With the help of her friend Sir Charles, Agatha investigates the strangling. All the suspects are present at the dance, and they include several of Agatha's enemies: George Selby, a local shopkeeper who recalls Agatha's attraction to his wife; Melissa Sheppard, who hosts the village soap opera and is jealous of Agatha; and Harry Perry, the local publican, who has been carrying on with Agatha's friend, Wilkes. Agatha's former assistant, Roy Silver, is also in town, working for a tabloid newspaper. He's afraid that his job is on the line unless he can find a headline story, and is therefore eager to help Agatha.

As Agatha investigates, she begins to wonder if the murder is connected to the prophecy of happiness. Could it be that the killer is trying to ensure that Agatha's life remains hopeless? She'll have to solve the crime before she becomes the next victim.

Magic for Marigold is a 1958 novel by Betty Smith, author of A Tree Grows in Brooklyn. It was Smith's second published novel, and was written 18 years after the publication of her first. Magic for Marigold tells the story of a young girl named Marigold Briggs, and is set in the 1950s in the fictitious town of Genesis, Pennsylvania. Marigold's mother, Mary, died in childbirth, and her father, Charles, never recovered from this loss. In addition to raising her father's espresso cafe, Marigold also has to take care of him. Her father spends his time lamenting the fact that Mary, his beloved wife, is dead. As a result, he is indifferent to everything in his life, including his daughter. In fact, he is disdainful of her, and rarely speaks to her or acknowledges her in any way. Fortunately, Marigold has some good friends: Mrs. Muldoon, her father's assistant at the cafe, and Brad Bradford, a local newspaper writer. Brad likes Marigold because she is pretty, gentle, and sweet; he eventually asks her to marry him. Also, the owner of the espresso cafe next door, Italian immigrant Gino Paggi, takes Marigold under his wing and teaches her about life, how to make pasta, and how to appreciate opera. He becomes a sort of father figure to her, teaching her about both life and coffee. About a year after Mary's death, Charles decides to sell the cafe and move to Florida, and Marigold runs away because she does not want to leave Genesis and her friends. She eventually returns home, and Charles sells the cafe to Gino. Brad ultimately breaks up with Marigold because he realizes that she is in love with Gino, and Marigold and Gino get married and move to Italy.

The novel follows the story of an Irish revolutionary, who flees Dublin after a bungled uprising and is forced to wander the countryside as a beggar. While walking through the Irish countryside, he is mocked by peasants for his revolutionary ideals, but finds sympathy from a young peasant woman. The two fall in love and have a child, but the revolutionary's guilty conscience over his other children and his participation in the uprising separate him from her. He eventually returns to Dublin and becomes a successful lawyer, but is haunted by his past and the death of his young lover. 

Ultimately, the revolutionary chooses to return to the countryside and reunite with his young lover's ghost on her deathbed. The novel was praised for its emotional power and became a bestseller in Ireland.

Peter Simple is a novel by Frederick Marryat, first published in 1834. The novel follows the adventures of Peter Simple, a young midshipman in the Royal Navy during the Napoleonic Wars.

The novel begins with Peter's father, a country doctor, urging him to join the navy as a way to make a career for himself. Peter is initially reluctant, but eventually agrees and is appointed to the HMS Trident, commanded by Captain Wilson.

On board the Trident, Peter struggles to fit in with the other midshipmen, who are all from more prestigious backgrounds than he is. He is bullied by the other midshipmen, who nickname him "Simple" due to his rural accent and lack of knowledge about the world. Despite these challenges, Peter works hard and eventually earns the respect of his fellow sailors.

The Trident is eventually sent to the Mediterranean to join the British fleet under the command of Lord Collingwood. Peter plays a key role in several battles, including the Battle of Cape Vincent and the Battle of Trafalgar.

After the Battle of Trafalgar, Peter is promoted to lieutenant and given command of a small vessel. He continues to serve with the navy, earning further promotions and distinctions. Eventually, he marries and settles down on a farm in Norfolk.

Peter Simple is a classic novel of the Napoleonic Wars, offering a glimpse into the life of a midshipman in the Royal Navy during this period. It is known for its humorous and satirical tone, as well as its detailed descriptions of life at sea.

The Big Orange Splot is a novel written by Daniel Pinkwater and published in 1984. It follows the story of a young boy named Vernon, who is obsessed with oranges. He lives in a "splot," or an area of town, that is home to many different groups of people. These include the "Scrubbers," who spend their time cleaning the city, and the "Plott Hoppers," who jump around from one plot to another. Vernon's favorite place is the Orange Store, which is run by a man named Mr. Orange.

One day, Vernon discovers that Mr. Orange has disappeared, and the Orange Store has been taken over by a man named Mr. Green. Vernon learns that Mr. Green plans to destroy the Orange Store and build a factory in its place. Vernon and his friends, including a young girl named Monica and a dog named Zero, set out to save the Orange Store. They must face many challenges and dangers, including a group of police officers who are working with Mr. Green.

Ultimately, Vernon and his friends are successful in saving the Orange Store. Mr. Orange is found and returns to run the store again, and Vernon's obsession with oranges is fulfilled when he receives an eternal supply of orange soda. The novel ends with Vernon and his friends enjoying the orange soda and the rest of their day in the sun.

In 1896, Sidi Mohammed ben Ali El Glaoui, Sovereign of Morocco, proclaims colonial peace with France. Nevertheless, French troops begin occupying the Moroccan Highlands. The son of the caid of Kouta, Mehhdi El Glaoui, nicknamed "Le lieutenant de Kouta", refuses to let a French detachment pass through his territory. The French captain Auboyneau, headed for Sijilmassa with a small group of soldiers, is ambushed and killed by the lieutenant. The French authorities respond by attacking the lieutenant's fortress. They are ambushed by the Berbers and forced to retreat.

A Auboyneau cousin, Captain Robert Auboyneau, is sent to Morocco to avenge his cousin's death. He is assisted by Lieutenant Truffant and Sergeant Becdin. The three soldiers find refuge in the house of Oued As-Salem caid Bouamama and his family, whose generosity gets the better of them. Becdin begins to develop feelings for Halima, the caid's sister. Meanwhile, Le lieutenant de Kouta is informed that the French have occupied his fortress. He attacks them with his warriors but is outnumbered and forced to retreat.

The soldiers spend the night with Bouamama's family. The next day, they leave Halima in the caid's house and set off in pursuit of Le lieutenant de Kouta. They are attacked by Berber warriors but manage to escape. Meanwhile, Le lieutenant de Kouta takes refuge in the mountain and prepares for a final battle against the French. Captain Auboyneau decides to grant Le lieutenant de Kouta an honorable surrender. Le lieutenant de Kouta is given a sword and led away.

"Glasshouse" is a 2013 novel by Australian author Caroline Overington. It follows the story of three women working at a women's magazine, whose lives converge during a charity bachelor auction. 

At the Tri-State Magazine annual charity bachelor auction, the three winners are each awarded a date with the handsome but mysterious Nate. They include Phoebe, the editor of the magazine, who is trying unsuccessfully to adopt a child; Lauren, the newly promoted junior editor; and Grace, a domestic violence counselor who is struggling to help a woman who refuses to leave her abusive husband. 

As the three women get to know Nate, they begin to question his motives and whether he is really who he says he is, and they start to wonder if he has set his sights on them specifically. At the same time, they learn that the magazine is planning to shutter the print edition and focus solely on online content, which will result in layoffs and leave all of them vulnerable to unemployment. As they try to navigate these challenges, they find themselves drawn to each other and form an unlikely alliance. 

As they work to uncover Nate's true identity and motives, they discover that he has a dark past that he has been trying to leave behind. At the same time, they must also confront their own pasts and the secrets that they have been keeping from each other. 

"Glasshouse" is a thrilling and suspenseful novel that explores the complexities of female friendship, the challenges of balancing work and personal life, and the power of forgiveness. It is a must-read for fans of psychological thrillers and women's fiction.

The story is about a couple, Aloysius Pendergast and his wife Helen, who live in a house in a fashionable street in New York City with their two children, Helen and Randolph. Aloysius earns his living as a successful actor, but he tires of the life of a star and is happy to leave it behind him for a life in the country when he inherits a small estate, Burnings, from a distant cousin.

The family moves into Burnings, and ALOYSIUS at once sets to work to turn the place into a show place. He plans to give up the stage altogether and settle down as a country gentleman. But life among the savages, namely his wife's indulgent family, the Whipples, slows his plans. He finds himself continually called upon to lend a hand with a mortgage, an investment, or some such matter, and one of his sons develops what appears to be typhoid.

Meanwhile, his wife has found a project of her own. She decides to train the two servants, Zuzu and Johnny, who have come with the house, to be perfect servants. Rather than allow them to do their own work in their own way, she constantly interferes and takes over, with the result that they lose the desire to work for themselves. They love their mistress, however, and are always ready to do anything for her. They tolerate her husband, but consider him something of a fool.

There are several subplots, including an old love of Helen's who comes to visit and a friendly rivalry with a neighbor, but the main story centers on the struggle between Aloysius and the Whipples. Neither side will give way, and as a result, Aloysius decides that they must get out of the house and leave the Whipples in peace. The family moves into a hotel in the nearest town while they look for a new home. There is a happy ending when the Whipples realize that they have gone too far and make an effort to mend their ways, and the Pendergasts move back home.

March to the Stars is a novel written by John Barnes, published in 2000. It portrays an alternate history of human space exploration in which NASA continued to exist as a national space agency in an alternate timeline in which the Soviet Union never collapsed. In this timeline, the NASA space program continues to exist in the 2020s, and missions utilizing the hardware of the cancelled Apollo program enable the first humans to reach the moons of Jupiter and orbit Saturn in the 2050s.

In the 1990s, NASA's continued existence is threatened by cutbacks, rivalry from privately funded space efforts, and corruption within the agency. The novel's protagonist, Nancy Hendrickson, is a NASA internal auditor, widowed with a young son, who uncovers a embezzlement and extortion scheme being run by insiders who plan to bankrupt the agency and ruin the US space program. Nancy must find a way to stop them, while also coming to terms with her negative and fearful reactions to her son's inoculation with the HIV virus in an effort to protect him from AIDS.

Most of the story takes place on Isle-­land, a fictional island off the coast of Maine, and its chief settlement, ­Sealhold. Sealhold is a ­fortified coastal settlement currently ruled by Keriall´s son, Maddox. A retrospective narrative begins in 560 AS, when Dugald cryptocurrency, a ­merchant captain and explorer first mapped Isle-­land. In 3160 AS, a group of­ Islanders fled to the ­safety of the stone shelters ­built in the depths of a ­mountain gorge to escape a lethal virus that had wiped out almost all the world´s population. The descendants of these survivors remained in the shelters for almost two centuries, slowly emerging in 281 AS. As a result of inbreeding and ­interbreeding with the ­uninhabited island's ­indigenous wildlife, they developed a mutation that enabled them to photosynthesize like plants, ­consuming sunlight and ­extracting nutrition from the air. This mutation also gave them enhanced ­perception and ­psychic abilities. 

Over the following centuries, the descendants of these ­Islanders, now known as the Gaels, became merchants and sailors, ranging as far as the coast of Ireland and Wales. They retained their genetic mutations and enhanced abilities, becoming physiologically superior to the ­non-­mutated survivors of the virus who rebuilt the world's population. Those non-­mutated survivors were ­eventually able to develop combustion engines and other technology, while the Gaels retained a ­pre-­industrial culture combined with a small amount of ­magical or supernatural ability. 

The Gaels built three ­shelters in the ­Isles, the most ­magnificent of which is ­Sealhold, the setting of most of the novel. There are roughly 1,500 people living in Sealhold, with another 6,000 living in the other, smaller settlements across Isle-­land. Maddox and his ­advisors, who wield ­significant political and spiritual power, have presided over a period of stability and ­prosperity for the Gaels.

Several families live alongside the banks of the Athabasca River in northern Alberta, a populous region of Treaty 6 territory. The novel focuses on one family in particular, that of Tom Native, a successful lawyer in his mid-thirties. Tom's father, Joseph, a former residential school student, survives by trapping but is bitter and alcoholic. Tom's mother, Alice, who comes from the prosperous Alcock family, had married Joseph against the wishes of her family. Tom's younger sister, Emily, prepares to leave for law school in Vancouver, hoping to avoid the pitfalls of love she sees in her parents' relationship. Tom, sensing the impending death of his father, feels lost and restless.

While working at his law firm in the city, Tom meets Emily's old university friend, Lisa Ivanov, who has just arrived from Vancouver. Lisa, originally from Kiev, Ukraine, came to Canada as a graduate student; her initial interest in Native people was sparked by her grandfather, a historian of Ukrainian descent who taught her that Ukraine was the homeland of the Cossacks, who were portrayed in Western history as "the scourge of all things Native." Lisa now writes popular romance novels under a pseudonym. Tom is smitten by Lisa and they begin a passionate affair.

The only thing that keeps her family together and safe is the promise they made to each other before she died, which the daughters later learn is that if any member was ever possessed by either God or Satan himself, then there could never be peace because they would all become insane. They find an alternative solution; instead of living separate lives with their relatives, they will go live apart so they can keep each other company during a series of increasingly powerful events.
